messageBody:
I would tend to agree. Unless the getters and setters
are private or protected or something, why bother with

the inner class? When I'm writing a test for
getters/setters, I'll just throw in some good values,
throw in some bad values, and make sure the getter
gives me back what it is supposed to. For example, if
protecting against having a null value in a String
field, I'd test something like:

------------------------------
theObject.setValue(null);
assertNotNull(theObject.getValue());
assertEquals("", theObject.getValue());

theObject.setValue("");
assertEquals("", theObject.getValue());

theObject.setValue("goodValue");
assertEquals("goodValue", theObject.getValue());

theObject.setValue(null);
assertEquals("goodValue", theObject.getValue());
-------------------------------

Or something like that :)

-Eric

--- Robert Wenner <robert@...> wrote:
> On Wednesday 01 May 2002 20:27, raju99 wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> > I am trying to answer the following question for
> myself -
> > "What is the best approach for testing get/set
> methods ?"
> >
>
> Why don't you just combine these tests without the
> inner class?
>
> car.setColor (blue);
> assert_equal (car.getColor, blue);
>
> I would not like modifying production code (adding
> classes) just for
> test purposes.
>
> Robert
